title: 104_hr2083
content: The Act titled "Tax Reduction and Economic Growth Act of 1995" allows for tax reduction in the event of low growth. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must notify the President and Congress if economic growth is below 1.5% and national unemployment is above 6.5% for specific testing periods. After notification of economic indicators, the President may authorize temporary tax reductions for a specified calendar year to stimulate the economy. The declaration must be transmitted to Congress. The President can authorize temporary tax reductions for a specific calendar year to stimulate the economy by transmitting a declaration to Congress. This includes reducing tax rates for the first income bracket and adjusting tax amounts in the tables. The President can authorize temporary tax reductions by transmitting a declaration to Congress. This includes adjusting tax amounts in the tables and modifying withholding procedures to reflect the rate reduction. If economic growth requirements are met, a temporary surtax may be implemented for subsequent taxable years. Effective for taxable years beginning in the first subsequent calendar year for which the economic growth requirements are met, tax rates in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be increased, except for individuals with Adjusted Gross Income below $50,000. For taxable years beginning in the first subsequent calendar year meeting economic growth requirements, tax rates in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will increase. Taxpayers filing jointly with Adjusted Gross Income below $75,000 will not exceed prior year rates, and withholding tables will be adjusted to reflect rate increases. The tax rates in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will increase to reflect the economic growth requirements. The President must determine if economic growth is above 4.5% and national unemployment is below 5.5% for the tax rates to increase. The President will determine a percentage increase in tax rates under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to offset any decrease in receipts, without raising taxes for individuals with Adjusted Gross Income below certain thresholds. This percentage will be published in the Federal Register before the start of the calendar year. The percentage increase in tax rates under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be determined by the President to offset any decrease in receipts, without raising taxes for individuals with Adjusted Gross Income below certain thresholds. This percentage will be published in the Federal Register before the beginning of the calendar year when the economic requirements are met. SEC. 3 of the Act states that any changes in receipts from the Act will not be considered under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
